I found this interview compelling and thought a couple of times how I'd love to take her classes. Here's someone who has lived in Turkey, come here, thrived, and so has a unique view of our country and its current situation.
This is about race b/c, as she notes, it begins after Charleston and learning about Confederate flag being re-raised after Civil Rights Act passed.
We have such animus towards anyone pointing out our obvious racial problems. Comments here prove some of her points about how a dominator takes any perceived criticism, even if on a problem obvious to all.
Yet the concern she astutely describes towards the end, the global corporate interests benefitting from democracy's paralysis, is our real enemy---not each other. Social democracy is already dead here on a bipartisan basis. It's been slowly strangled over time and just now can really see it.
I share the professor's concerns over our democracy, and just as anywhere it will be the poor of any color who will suffer the most, a group enlarging daily.

If conservative's have an insidious long term plan to make everyone despise government by making it a royal pain in the butt, "means testing" everywhere possible is one way to do it.

I thought for a while Ross had seen the light. But then came this:

".....entitlement reform, an area where I think the would-be benefit cutters are right, the party’s pro-reform politicians have gotten somewhat better about framing reform in terms of means-testing and having upper-income seniors pay a little more...."

The word "entitlement" has been perverted to convey the opposite of what it really means - something you are entitled to. Not that SS is in dire straits anyway, even though the right wants to make it sound that way.

A means-test takes account of income already received to calculate what the next year's benefit would be. Why would anyone want to needlessly add another layer of administration to the calculation and distribution of benefits when there already exist two built-in mechanisms to achieve the same effect?

First, the FICA withholding which is a percentage of income up to the cap. Both of those are easily changed. It's easy to envisage tweaking SS (and that's all it needs) by raising the cap up front while even lowering the percentage withheld.

Secondly, SS income up is taxed at existing tax rates, under an existing formula which, incidentally, leaves 15% of it untaxed even at the highest total incomes.

For conservatives who supposedly want small government, means-testing represents the ultimate government intrusion. Maybe it would be their way of trying to discredit SS. one of the programs they have always reviled.

James Comey is discovering that just as truth and principles were unwanted in the Bush Administration (nobody wanted to hear that this great new wiretapping program is illegal) they are unwelcome in the Obama administration as well. Police unions do not want to be told to reform, Republicans want to bludgeon the Administration, professional activists want to bludgeon the police, and the President needs one more legislative feather in his cap for the library before he leaves. There are no friends inside the Beltway; only interests.

Comey is probably the only person in Washington who actually remembers that criminal justice should be about saving lives instead advancing political careers. Urban homicides are up 20% this year so far across three dozen major cities. That fact should bring about pause, but instead it only seems to bring about denial from just about everybody.

If a President publicly ignored the strategic advice of all his military policy makers when making war decisions he would be pilloried. So why is Obama applauded for ignoring the law enforcement advice provided by his top law enforcement expert?

I think Comey has injected much needed commentary into the recent discussion about police behavior, and doing so at the University of Chicago may not have been accidental, as it is the birthplace of the intersection of law and economics.  Regardless of what one thinks of abuses related to "stop&frisk", economic theory dictates that there would an increase in crime with the end of such practices because criminals would calculate that the probability of being stopped would be reduced.   While it is too soon to say definitively this has occurred because there is only 1-2 years of new data, the trend of increased crime supports the theory.  The politicians and the public must soon decide whether the benefits in reduced policing outweigh the increase in crime.

OK, then, what is to be done with the disrupters? I agree they can drag down the rest of the class, but to just stick them in time-out doesn't really solve much. They get further and further behind in their schoolwork, and the outcome is likely dismal.

is it fair to other students are trying to learn? My sister taught in the NYC "system" in many neighborhoods for over 30 years. The most important thing for a teacher to be successful is to gain and maintain CONTROL of his/her classroom.

If one student is disruptive and prevents the entire class from moving forward, yes, they have got to leave that classroom. If the disruptive behavior is persistent, they have "go to go". Most, not all, parents expect to send their kids to school and let the teachers take on the responsibility of being teacher and parent. But, you know what? It's the parent, or parents' responsibility and duty to make sure their little darlings know, understand AND follow the rules of the school.

The problem is not that charter schools remove obstreperous students, but that public schools cannot.  Disruptive students must be removed quickly and firmly, even if for only the reminder of a given period.  The adage justice delayed is justice denied is never more true than in grammar schools:  if a child is preventing the rest of a class from learning, s/he must be immediately removed to the gym, office, time-out room or whatever.  I have taught in Watts, South Central, and East LA and at the high school and middle school level.  The most effective classes exist at the schools that are most effective of immediately pulling disruptive children from the class.  Is it great if they get immediate attention, psychological and/or mental in their new environment?  Of course.  But even if they don't, for the benefit of the class they've just left, they must be removed.  Public schools aren't about teaching every last child every last item in a lesson plan.  They, like libraries, parks, and other public goods are about "the greatest good for the greatest number."

I'm sure that there are a myriad of African children living in small villages who would jump at the chance to be educated at schools like the Success Academy who spend over $19,000 per student.  Not only do public schools feed children both breakfast & lunch at no cost if the parents are impoverished, but the schools are also expected to teach children how to behave, socialize, cooperate, communicate, love one another regardless of color of skin, empathize, display random acts of kindness & have a lifelong love of learning.  Meanwhile parents who have the TV on for hours at a time, have little to no reading materials on hand in the home or show limited disciplinary skills at home, expect the schools to do their job or else will be the first to complain to high heaven about how unfair the school is.  There should really be more accountability placed on incompetent & negligent parents rather than focusing exclusively on the school when attributing blame for children's poor performance.
Unfortunately I have seen desk "pushing", screaming tantrums, running away not only from staff but attempting to run off school grounds.  This was a 7-8 year old child.

One has to wonder to what edge these 4 and 5 year olds are pushed in order to understand the tantrums. I've been involved with the younger grades for years, and I've never seen a child push a desk. The desk pushing sounds exactly like the story Moskowitz had in her press release demanding a retraction from PBS about suspensions at Success Academy. Who knows how exaggerated the desk stories are? How inexperienced are the teachers and the principals? How un-engaging are the lessons, where children as young as 4 must sit with feet down, backs straight, hands folded and eyes following the teacher all day. Bad grades are published and children shamed. What about the breaking story that Eva has FIVE Universal Pre-K classes at her schools, at $10,000 per child (72 children), yet REFUSES TO SIGN A CONTRACT WITH THE DOE. Therefore, monitors cannot come into the rooms, and her budgets are not checked. Since U Pre-K teachers must be certified in the area, and since they all have to attend 3 day Summer Sessions, with a follow-up on Election Day, how does she alone get away with this? Carmen Farina and Mayor deBlasio - answers please! The SUNY Charter Institute must also be held accountable for failing to look into the attrition and suspension rates. Answers, please! Cuomo, you allowed yourself to be led by the nose by Moskowitz with your skewering of de Blasio and speaking behind a podium that said, "Charters Work!" You took millions from her hedge fund friends. Answers, please.
Can someone tell me the solution to disruptive students? If all students are entitled to an education, what is in place to protect non-disruptive students?

Of course schools shouldn't be cherry picking students. But what's missing is the overall discussion of really badly behaved disruptive students and their parents accountability for this behavior. As a former urban public school teacher I can honestly say that disruptive behavior is one of the major obstacles that nobody wants to deal with.
My nephew attends the #1 public high school in New Jersey.  I'm not worrying about academic armageddon this generation.

The reason so many parents fight to get their kids into SA is because at least for their children in the inner cities there is no quality education though the public system.  They are concerned about the here and now, and believe these charters give their children a better chance of a good education.

We've been telling you this all along.  Charter Schools are what one might call institutional shape shifters.  They seem good now. If left to proliferate, it will be the beginning of the end of quality education in the USA.

The problem is neighborhood public schools and charter public schools are judged by the same metrics even though they have very different populations. If Charters want public funds, let them take all who arrive at the door just like neighborhood schools.

What I take from this is because charter schools are free to function on their own, they can, for example, raise standards that public schools can't and run the facility like a gifted school. Even though these schools are run on a lottery, kids who get in have to perform behaviorally and academically to these higher standards, and ones who fall behind are either expelled, told they should leave, or drop out and go to a public school.

Ellen- should education always happen in the classroom? By involving children and families in civic participation, we allow everyone to do a reality check and question a system that has some major cancers. Or should the kids be made to stay in their seats and be force fed test prep in the name of public education?
